pageData.text: Muscle cells are cells that are specialized to contract. The muscle cells are long and thin. Cells of this type are arranged parallel to each other. There are three main types of muscle tissue:

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Skeletal muscle tissue</button> is connected to the skeleton, and its main function is movement of the body.
<button class='glossary-text'>Smooth muscles</button> are located in the visceral organs and locations where there is a need for support and a way to close off or open passages, such as arteries.
The third and last type is <button class='glossary-text'>cardiac muscle</button>, which is solely located in the heart.

pageData.text: In this investigation, students examine these three muscle types.

text: Compare and contrast <button class='glossary-text'>smooth</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>skeletal</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>cardiac muscle tissue</button> based on their histology, locations, and functions.
Identify the different layers of a skeletal muscle.
Describe the organization of a skeletal muscle fiber, including the function of each structure.

pageData.text: There are about 600 muscles in the human body. One of the strongest and longest muscle groups in the human body is made up of the buttock muscles, known informally as “glutes” - the gluteus maximus, gluteus minimus, and gluteus medius. One of the major functions of the gluteus maximus is to work against gravity when walking up stairs. This muscle group is also extremely important when someone is performing heavy lifting as it helps support and protect the lower back from strain.When looking to strengthen these muscles, it is important to know their structure. There are two different ways to look at muscles in this context: fast-twitch muscles have fibers structured for short, powerful bursts of energy and are best strengthened by lifting weights; slow-twitch muscles are structured for endurance activities. A common misconception is that glutes are fast-twitch muscles; however, they are made up of both fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscles. When trying to strengthen the glutes, it is necessary to perform a variety of exercises, such as squats, lunges, deadlifts, donkey kicks, glute/ham raises, and hip thrusters.

pageData.desc: A man in exercise clothing in a low squat with his hands on the floor in front of him as if about to extend his legs behind him in a donkey kick motion.
pageData.altText: A man in exercise clothing in a low squat with his hands on the floor in front of him as if about to extend his legs behind him in a donkey kick motion.

pageData.text: Muscles are found throughout the body. The 3 types of muscle tissue are <button class='glossary-text'>skeletal muscle</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>cardiac muscle</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>smooth muscle</button>. Muscles allow the body to do everything from walking, to pumping blood, to churning food in the stomach.

pageData.subTitle: Types of Muscle Cells
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Cardiac muscle</button> is an involuntary tissue located in the heart. Cardiac muscle contains <button class='glossary-text'>intercalated discs</button>, and the cells appear branched and striated. Each cell contains a single nucleus.

<button class='glossary-text'>Smooth muscle</button> is an involuntary tissue found in the walls of organs like the stomach, intestines, and blood vessels. The cells are wide in the middle and narrow on the ends. Each contains a single nucleus.
<button class='glossary-text'>Skeletal muscle</button> is a voluntary tissue and is commonly found attached to bone by tendons. The cells are striated and each contains multiple nuclei.

pageData.subTitle: Skeletal muscle
pageData.text: A <button class='glossary-text'>sarcomere</button> is the contractile unit within a muscle. <button class='glossary-text'>Thin filaments</button> are pulled along <button class='glossary-text'>thick filaments</button> toward the midline (M-line) to shorten the muscle fiber, resulting in a contraction of the fiber. When multiple muscle fibers contract, the entire muscle shortens.

Muscle tissue is composed of long, thin muscle cells called <button class='glossary-text'>myocytes</button>. These myocytes are arranged parallel to each other and contract. Their main function is to create movement. There are three types of muscle tissue: <button class='glossary-text'>skeletal</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>cardiac</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>smooth muscle</button>.

Skeletal muscle is attached to bone and is responsible for voluntary movement. This muscle type is made up of long, striated cells. The striations are due to the arrangement of the in the contractile units, called , along the length of the cell. These sarcomeres are grouped inside a muscle cell, which causes a very distinct banding pattern (see Figure 1). These cells contain several nuclei and are therefore called . The nuclei are pushed to the sides of the cells next to the . The plasma membranes in muscle tissue are also known as . Inside each muscle cell are (see Figure 2). A myofibril is made up of alternating protein filaments known as myofilaments. The consists mainly of myosin and is responsible for generating contractile force. The is mainly actin, which the myosin pulls against during contraction. The myofilaments repeat along the length of the myofibril in organized units (sarcomeres).

image.altText: Figure 1: The distinct banding pattern of sarcomeres in the muscle fiber
Figure 2: The sarcomere inside the myofibril inside the muscle fiber

altText: Figure 1: The distinct banding pattern of sarcomeres in the muscle fiber
Figure 2: The sarcomere inside the myofibril inside the muscle fiber

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>sarcomere</button> is the structural unit of the <button class='glossary-text'>myofibril</button>. Under microscopic examination, a series of sarcomeres appears as an alternating set of dark and light bands. The dark bands are called the <button class='glossary-text'>A-bands</button>; this is the area where the sarcomere will contract. The lighter <button class='glossary-text'>I-bands</button> contain <button class='glossary-text'>Z-discs</button>; this is the location where the <button class='glossary-text'>thin filaments</button> are attached and where they are pulled closer together during a contraction. The A-bands and the I-bands should be clearly visible on a slide containing <button class='glossary-text'>skeletal muscle</button>. The Z-discs are best viewed with an electron microscope.

pageData.question: How are myocytes arranged in muscle tissue?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Myocytes are arranged parallel to each other and contract.

pageData.question: Which of the following structures is most responsible for the banding pattern characteristic of striated muscle tissue?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Under microscopic examination, a series of sarcomeres appears as an alternating set of dark and light bands.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Muscle tissue is composed of long, thin muscle cells (myocytes) arranged in parallel to create movement through contraction. For example, skeletal muscles are made up of long, striated cells containing myofibrils made up of alternating protein filaments known as myofilaments. The length of a myofibril can be organized in repeating contractile units called sarcomeres. The arrangement of the myofilaments within each sarcomere gives an alternating dark and light banding pattern that gives the myocytes their striations.

img.alt: Figure 2: The sarcomere inside the myofibril inside the muscle fiber

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Muscle tissue is composed of long, thin muscle cells (myocytes) arranged in parallel to create movement through contraction. For example, skeletal muscles are made up of long, striated cells containing myofibrils made up of alternating protein filaments known as myofilaments. The length of a myofibril can be organized in repeating contractile units called sarcomeres. The arrangement of the myofilaments within each sarcomere gives an alternating dark and light banding pattern that gives the myocytes their striations.

img.alt: Figure 2: The sarcomere inside the myofibril inside the muscle fiber

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Cardiac muscle</button> makes up part of the wall of the heart and is also striated. This muscle type is located only in the heart and contracts rhythmically. This muscle type is under the control of the involuntary nervous system. Two nodes of the cardiac conduction system, the <button class='glossary-text'>AV</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>SA nodes</button>, are responsible for maintaining the heart rate. These nodes can maintain this base rhythm even after the heart is removed from the body, as long as nutrients and oxygen are supplied. Cardiac muscle cells have only one nucleus, but they do contain the same striations that can be seen in <button class='glossary-text'>skeletal muscle</button> (see Figure 3). The connections between the different cardiac muscle cells are called <button class='glossary-text'>intercalated discs</button>. These discs improve the speed of muscle contraction and ensure that the force of the contraction goes through all the cells.
This muscle type contains a high abundance of small blood vessels, called capillaries, that transport oxygen and nutrients to the muscle.

is found in the walls of most internal organs and lacks striations (see Figure 4). Depending on location, cells of smooth muscle may be slender and spindle shaped (gastrointestinal tract), short and thick (walls of small arteries), or folded and twisted (walls of large blood arteries). Generally, they are densely packed and are connected at overlapping portions. This type of muscle contracts more slowly than skeletal muscle but can maintain sustained contractions. Smooth muscle is responsible for involuntary movements.

image.altText: Figure 3: The intercalated discs and nucleus in a cardiac muscle
Figure 4: Smooth muscle with the nucleus labeled

altText: Figure 3: The intercalated discs and nucleus in a cardiac muscle
Figure 4: Smooth muscle with the nucleus labeled

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the difference between the appearance of skeletal muscle and cardiac muscle?

options.text: Skeletal muscle lacks intercalated discs; cardiac muscle features intercalated discs
Skeletal muscle cells have one nucleus; cardiac muscle cells have many nuclei.
Skeletal muscle features striations; cardiac muscle lacks striations.
Skeletal muscle features nodes; cardiac muscle lacks nodes.
Skeletal muscle lacks myofilaments; cardiac muscle features myofilaments.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Skeletal and cardiac muscle look similar due to their striations but differ in that skeletal muscle cells are multinucleate and cardiac muscle cells feature intercalated discs.

pageData.question: Which of the following structures of cardiac muscle improves its ability to contract rhythmically?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Intercalated discs speed up muscle contraction and ensure that the force of the contraction goes through all the cells.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Cardiac muscle makes up part of the wall of the heart and is also striated. This muscle type is located only in the heart and contracts rhythmically. To facilitate this unique movement, cardiac myocytes feature intercalated discs that connect them to one another in a way that improves the speed of muscle contraction and ensures that the force of the contraction goes through all the cells. These cells have only one nucleus, unlike skeletal muscle which is multinucleate.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Cardiac muscle makes up part of the wall of the heart and is also striated. This muscle type is located only in the heart and contracts rhythmically. To facilitate this unique movement, cardiac myocytes feature intercalated discs that connect them to one another in a way that improves the speed of muscle contraction and ensures that the force of the contraction goes through all the cells. These cells have only one nucleus, unlike skeletal muscle which is multinucleate.

pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, set up the microscope. In Activity 1, you will place the slide on the stage and focus on a muscle tissue type in the field of view. Next, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify structures of the magnified tissue. Then, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation. You will repeat this process for each muscle tissue type on the slide. Lastly, compare the characteristics of each muscle type.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Ensure that any broken or discarded microscope slides are disposed of properly. Put them in a hard-sided container (such as a small, sturdy cardboard box) before placing them in the household trash.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is the contractile unit of a striated muscle cell?
Which of the following best describes the structure of a muscle cell from smallest to largest?
Which of the following describes one difference between skeletal muscle and cardiac muscle?

options.text: Skeletal muscle has multinucleate cells; cardiac muscle has mononucleate cells.
Skeletal muscle is striated; cardiac muscle lacks striations.
Skeletal muscle contracts involuntarily; cardiac muscle contracts voluntarily.
Skeletal muscle features intercalated discs; cardiac muscle cells feature Z-discs.
Skeletal muscle features sarcomeres; cardiac muscle lacks sarcomeres.

Select a work area that is near an electrical outlet if using a corded microscope.
Obtain all listed needed materials. (Remember: when carrying your microscope, grasp it by the arm and support the base.)
Familiarize yourself with your microscope. Identify its key parts. Consult the instructions that came with your microscope if you have any difficulty finding a specific part.
Note: If your microscope has an oil immersion (100x) objective, identify it but do not use it during this investigation.

Be aware of your instructor’s directions for documenting your work. You may be asked to draw pictures and either photograph or scan them for submission, or you may need to take pictures through the microscope using a digital camera or mobile device. To learn how to take photos through the microscope, see the following video:
In Activity 1, you will examine each muscle type on the slide under the microscope. Then, you will identify and compare their characteristics.
Examine the muscle slide; note that it contains all three types of muscle.
Place the slide on the microscope stage.
Note: Remember, the label should be faceup on the left.
Center and focus the slide in the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section with well-defined <button class='glossary-text'>skeletal muscle</button>. Now increase the magnification of the microscope.
Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and indicate the multiple nuclei striations.

In Data Table 1, write down the answers to the following questions: What makes this skeletal muscle type stand out? What were the main details you could observe? Also, record the total magnification needed to best view the object.
Return to the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section with <button class='glossary-text'>cardiac muscle</button>. Now increase the magnification of the microscope.
Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and indicate nuclei and <button class='glossary-text'>intercalated discs</button>.
In Data Table 1, write down what makes this cardiac muscle look different from the skeletal muscle. Also, record the total magnification needed to best view the object.
Return to the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section with <button class='glossary-text'>smooth muscle</button>. Now increase the magnification of the microscope.
Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and indicate nuclei and shape of the cells.
In Data Table 1, write down what makes this smooth muscle look different from the other two muscle types. Also, record the total magnification needed to best view the object.

How to Handle, Store, and Repair Microscope Slides

data.title: A-bands
data.content: The areas where a sarcomere contracts; they appear as dark bands when a series of sarcomeres are under microscopic examination

data.title: AV node
data.content: Located in the inferior area of the right atrium of the heart, just above the right ventricle; it imposes a slight delay (approximately 0.1 second) on the signal from the SA node; stands for atrioventricular node

data.title: Cardiac muscle tissue
data.content: The type of muscle tissue that makes up the walls of the heart, and has striations (stripes) that are often not as pronounced as those of skeletal muscle; its fibers are arranged parallel to one another, but individual fibers often split into branches

data.title: I-bands
data.content: The areas of a sarcomere that contain Z-discs; they appear as light bands when a series of sarcomeres are under microscopic examination

data.title: Intercalated discs
data.content: The connections between adjacent cardiac muscle cells

data.title: Multinucleate
data.content: A cell that contains more than one nucleus

data.title: Myofibrils
data.content: Very fine contractile fibres that run in parallel columns along the length of striated (striped) muscle fibers

data.title: Myofilaments
data.content: The alternating protein filaments that make up myofibrils

data.title: Plasma membrane
data.content: The organelle that surrounds and defines each cell, and separates the cell's internal environment from its external environment

data.title: SA node
data.content: The node located in the superior and posterior region of the right atrium of the heart, and which generates the electrical signal for contraction and sets the basic heart rate; also called the pacemaker of the heart; stands for sinoatrial node

data.title: Sarcolemma
data.content: The plasma membranes in muscle tissue

data.title: Sarcomeres
data.content: Arrangements of myofilaments in the contractile units of some types of muscle cell that give some them a striated (striped) appearance

data.title: Skeletal muscle tissue
data.content: A type of muscle tissue made up of long, striated (striped) cells that are sometimes called muscle fibers

data.title: Smooth muscle
data.content: A type of muscle tissue found in the walls of most internal organs and which lacks striations (stripes); the cells have different shapes depending on their location in the body

data.title: Thick filament
data.content: A type of myofilament that consists mainly of myosin and which is responsible for generating contractile force in striated muscle cells

data.title: Thin filament
data.content: A type of myofilament that consists mainly of actin, which the myosin pulls against during contraction in striated (striped) muscle cells

data.title: Z-discs
data.content: The areas in a sarcomere where the thin filaments are attached and are pulled closer together during contraction; they can only be viewed with an electron microscope
